Docs.typeparam: The type of entity being queried.
Docs.param: The source query.
Docs.summary: The change tracker will not track any of the entities that are returned from a LINQ query. If the entity instances are modified, this will not be detected by the change tracker and will not persist those changes to the database.
Docs.returns: A new query where the result set will not be tracked by the context.

remarks.para: Disabling change tracking is useful for read-only scenarios because it avoids the overhead of setting up change tracking for each entity instance. You should not disable change tracking if you want to manipulate entity instances and persist those changes to the database using .
Identity resolution will not be performed. If an entity with a given key is in different result in the result set then they will be different instances.
The default tracking behavior for queries can be controlled by .
See No-tracking queries in EF Core for more information and examples.

Docs.typeparam: The type of entity being queried.
Docs.param: The source query.
Docs.summary: The change tracker will not track any of the entities that are returned from a LINQ query. If the entity instances are modified, this will not be detected by the change tracker and will not persist those changes to the database.

remarks.para: Disabling change tracking is useful for read-only scenarios because it avoids the overhead of setting up change tracking for each entity instance. You should not disable change tracking if you want to manipulate entity instances and persist those changes to the database using .

The default tracking behavior for queries can be controlled by .
See No-tracking queries in EF Core for more information and examples.

Docs.typeparam: The type of entity being queried.
Docs.param: The source query.
Indicates whether the query will track results or not.
Docs.summary: Returns a new query where the change tracker will either keep track of changes or not for all entities that are returned, depending on the value of the 'track' parameter. When tracking, Any modification to the entity instances will be detected and persisted to the database during . When not tracking, if the entity instances are modified, this will not be detected by the change tracker and will not persist those changes to the database.
Docs.returns: A new query where the result set will be tracked by the context.

remarks.para: Disabling change tracking is useful for read-only scenarios because it avoids the overhead of setting up change tracking for each entity instance. You should not disable change tracking if you want to manipulate entity instances and persist those changes to the database using .
The default tracking behavior for queries can be controlled by .
See Tracking queries in EF Core for more information and examples.

Docs.typeparam: To be added.
Docs.param: The source query.
Docs.summary: Deletes all database rows for the entity instances which match the LINQ query from the database.

remarks.para: This operation executes immediately against the database, rather than being deferred until is called. See Executing bulk operations with EF Core for more information and examples.

example.para:
The following query shows including a single level of related entities.
context.Blogs.Include(blog => blog.Posts);

The following query shows including multiple levels and branches of related data.
context.Blogs .Include(blog => blog.Posts).ThenInclude(post => post.Tags).ThenInclude(tag => tag.TagInfo) .Include(blog => blog.Contributors);
